node.text: Burgundy’s labels are decorative, even iconic; but they’re also a fascinating window onto the region’s social history. In this short video @wgfkelley explains why famous and little-heard-of producers share a label, and how this reminds us on the domaine bottling movement’s origins.

node.text: In the final part of the Burgundian Vignoble series @wgfkelley looks below the surface, at the drains and even cisterns that lie beneath the surface of some #Burgundian #vineyards, influencing their capacity to retain water or to remove an excess. He's seen eleventh-century cisterns in the Mâconnais, but this especially impressive example in the Côte de Nuits is around a century old. Burgundy is full of surprises!

node.title: Constructing the Burgundian Vignoble: Cisterns & Drains (Part 3 of 3)

node.text: In this video by @wgfkelley explains how powerful machinery came onto the scene in the late 20th century. Not only were murgers demolished and contours smoothed, but land previously unsuitable for planting was reclaimed. The commune of Meursault was a pioneer of this, using heavy machinery to pulverize stones in the Chaumes de Narvaux, Casse Têtes and Perrières. This new vineyard land was leased to young growers by the commune. Today, rather than removing stones by hand prior to replanting, it’s more and more common to see growers choosing to break up rocks mechanically and recontour their vineyards, which has consequences for soil structure. It’s another reminder that the Burgundian vignoble is a man made landscape...

node.title: Constructing the Burgundian Vignoble: Heavy Machinery (Part 2 of 3)

node.text: The #Burgundian landscape has been planted to vines for so long that it’s easy to forget that creating a #vineyard is often more complicated than merely planting vines. In this short video @wgfkelley discusses how, over the centuries, rocks were removed to build « murgers », create soils and smooth contours. Including a cameo by William's flower-gathering three year old daughter 🤣

node.title: Constructing the Burgundian Vignoble: The Landscape (Part 1 of 3)

node.text: In this short video, Emmanuel Guillot of @guillotbroux talks about restoring and replanting the abandoned walled #vineyards of Cruzille, overtaken by the forest in the aftermath of #phylloxera. A labor of love for future generations!

node.text: During a fascinating vertical tasting with @domainejmvincent we took time to visit the vineyards, including Jean-Marc’s high density plantings of #Chardonnay at the northern end of Les Gravières (where the soils are white marl, unlike the rest of this large climat). This domaine is one of @wgfkelley's favorites in Burgundy, and the 2019s are their best wines to date! But more about that soon in the pages of @wine_advocate

node.title: Jean-Marc Vincent on his high density plantings in Santenay

node.text: 🔊 SOUND ON: In this video, our #Champagne reviewer @wgfkelley discuss how Champagne ages - as well as how its aging trajectory differs from other wines - while opening a 1964 Royale Réserve from Philipponnat.

node.text: @michelebernetti brings us inside Marche and Abruzzo, two regions farmed by @umanironchi. Verdicchio and Montepulciano are discussed, and how did the Pecorino grape really get its name? This and more. Enjoy 🇮🇹 🍷

node.text: Castellina, Chianti Classico, Sangiovese, Maremma, LOVE ❤️ ART 🖼 and WINE 🍷 are topics of conversation with @fattorianittardi Léon Femfert.

node.title: @monicalarner chats with Léon Femfert of the beautiful @fattorianittardi

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Robert Parker Wine Advocate on August 03, 2021. May be an image of outdoors.

node.text:
RECENTLY PUBLISHED: Portugal, Port: A Potpourri of 2019s, Tawnies and LBVs.⁣
⁣⁣
⁣This report features the first serious look at some 2019s in bottle, plus some fine Tawnies and Late Bottled Vintage Ports (LBVs). Let’s start with the superstar. Quinta do Noval strikes gold with its Nacional, which just seems sensational at times... ⁣
⁣⁣
⁣Read @mark_squires_wine's and 10+ tasting notes via link in bio. ⁣
⁣⁣
⁣📸 : @quintadonoval_official⁣
⁣

node.text:
Robert Parker Green Emblem Recipient - Littorai Wines, California, USA.⁣
⁣⁣
⁣Having farmed conventionally for many years, Ted Lemon became interested in other ways of approaching agriculture. Although Littorai has become synonymous with biodynamic farming, Lemon eschews certifications and its role in marketing, driving home instead the notion that actions speak louder than words. ⁣
⁣⁣
⁣His philosophies incorporate several approaches to agriculture, including biodynamics, permaculture and agroecology, a combination he calls generative agriculture. Most (85%) of Littorai’s grapes are farmed biodynamically, while the remaining 15% are farmed organically. ⁣
⁣⁣
⁣More info via our bio link.⁣
⁣⁣
⁣📸: @littoraiwines

node.text:
RECENTLY PUBLISHED: Italy, Sicily, Etna: Introducing Idda, a New Project by Gaja and Graci.⁣
⁣⁣
⁣A volcano is introduced with a masculine pronoun in Italian, as in il volcano. In Sicilian dialect, however, Mount Etna, or Europe’s largest and most active volcano, is addressed with a female pronoun by those who live under her constant veiling of fine ash and dust. She is considered the “mother of all mountains” ('a muntagna) in Sicily, because her generous flanks embrace much of the triangular-shaped island...⁣
⁣⁣
⁣Two of Italian wine’s most important families, the Gaja clan based in Barbaresco and the Graci family of Catania, joined forces in 2017 to create a new wine company on Etna. They named it after the Sicilian word for “she,” Idda.⁣
⁣⁣
⁣Read @monicalarner's full report and tasting notes via link in bio. ⁣
⁣⁣
⁣📸: @monicalarner

node.text:
Robert Parker Green Emblem Recipient - Eyrie Vineyards, Oregon, USA.⁣
⁣⁣
⁣Vines at Eyrie have never been farmed conventionally—no herbicides or artificial pesticides have ever been used, and the land has never been tilled or irrigated. The estate has been certified organic since 2013. ⁣
⁣⁣
⁣Second-generation winemaker Jason Lett offers something more nontangible than certifications—viticultural heritage. Jason works fastidiously to preserve the old vines planted by his father. ⁣
⁣⁣
⁣In caring for the old vines at the estate, Jason has also preserved some unique varieties that perform well in Oregon apart from Pinot Noir and Chardonnay, grapes like Trousseau, Pinot Gris, Chasselas and Pinot Meunier.⁣
⁣⁣
⁣More info via our bio link.⁣
⁣⁣
⁣📸: @eyrievineyards

node.text:
Robert Parker Green Emblem Recipient - Ridge Vineyards,  Santa Cruz Mountains, USA.⁣
⁣⁣
⁣Ridge began transitioning from sustainable to organic farming in 2008, initiating the certification process block by block to mitigate risk. As the largest grower of organically certified grapes in the Santa Cruz Mountains and Sonoma County, it took several years to fully convert the vineyards.⁣
⁣⁣
⁣Former longtime Monte Bello winemaker Eric Baugher points out that commitment to sustainability extends to economics. Gaining organic certification is costly, and investments in sustainable systems for the winery involve huge upfront investments.⁣
⁣⁣
⁣Apart from their commitment to organic farming and sustainable winemaking, what is perhaps most striking about Ridge is transparency. They began including ingredient lists on labels in 2011, a move only a few others have made in the decade since. ⁣
⁣⁣
⁣More info via our bio link.⁣
⁣⁣
⁣📸: @ridgevineyards

node.text:
RECENTLY PUBLISHED: France: Odyssée – Bordeaux + Rhône Throwback Blending with a Twist. ⁣
⁣⁣
⁣Blending has been commonly practiced by winemakers for centuries, on a most basic level, to achieve better balance and otherwise improve the overall quality of the various individual parts by creating a more complex sum. While the modern fine wine trend is for wines to edge ever closer toward expressing a sense of place in the clearest, least manipulated way, it is worth noting that a sensitively blended wine that allows all its components to shine with compelling poise can be just as evocative as any single-vineyard, single-variety wine. Odyssée is one such wine.⁣
⁣⁣
⁣Read @lisapbmw's full report and tasting notes via link in bio. ⁣
⁣⁣
⁣📸 : @lisapbmw

node.text:
RECENTLY PUBLISHED: France, Burgundy, Côte Chalonnaise: Domaine Dureuil-Janthial’s Meix Cadot Vieilles Vignes, 1994-2019.⁣
⁣⁣
⁣Dureuil’s wines are increasingly sought after. His new releases are reviewed every year in these pages. Plans for a vertical tasting of his Meix Cadot Vieilles Vignes—the wine that made the biggest impression back in that first early-evening visit—finally came to fruition this spring. The results, recorded here, only reaffirmed his conviction that, when the Côte Chalonnaise’s best sites are meticulously farmed and intelligently vinified, they can produce truly great wines.⁣
⁣⁣
⁣Read @wgfkelley's full report and 20+ tasting notes via link in bio. ⁣
⁣⁣
⁣📸 : @wgfkelley⁣
⁣

node.text:
Robert Parker Green Emblem Recipient - Descendientes de José Palacios, Bierzo, Spain. ⁣
⁣⁣
⁣Biodynamic principles have been applied in Ricardo Pérez Palacios' vineyards since the beginning of this venture, in the harvest of 1999. Ricardo does what he does on principle and follows through. ⁣
⁣⁣
⁣Descendientes de José Palacios is the name of the adventure in Bierzo from uncle and nephew Álvaro Palacios and Ricardo Pérez Palacios. The vineyards are on steep slopes and the soils are shallow, with a slate base not present in the lower areas. This gives the wine a very different character. Álvaro Palacios defined it quite well many years ago: “This is something halfway between Burgundy and the Rhône.” The wines possess the subtlety and elegance of Burgundies and that wild touch of Syrah from the Northern Rhône⁣
⁣⁣
⁣More info via our bio link.⁣
⁣⁣
⁣📸: Descendientes de José Palacios

node.text:
RECENTLY PUBLISHED: Eastern Europe & Beyond: Bessa Valley (Bulgaria) and Sauk Dere (Russia). ⁣
⁣⁣
⁣The centerpiece of this report is Bessa Valley’s 2016s, on the occasion of its 20th anniversary. Bessa Valley has made impressive wines in Bulgaria for some time now. Count Stephan von Neipperg (Château Canon La Gaffelière and La Mondotte, among others) is a part owner and a face of the winery, although the main shareholder is Dr. Karl-Heinz Hauptmann. Marc Dworkin, who has also made a lot of wines in Bordeaux, is the enology consultant.⁣
⁣⁣
⁣Read @mark_squires_wine's full report and 10+ testing notes via link in bio.⁣
⁣⁣
⁣📸: Bessa Valley

node.text:
Robert Parker Green Emblem Recipient - Horsepower Vineyards, Walla Walla Valley, USA.⁣
⁣⁣
⁣As the name suggests, Horsepower Vineyards pays homage to winemaking traditions of centuries past, with Belgian draft horses as the driving force behind the winery. Horsepower continually strives to harmonize with Mother Nature to create the highest quality wines grown in their vineyards. Vigneron Christophe Baron and team are committed to the farming philosophies and practices of biodynamics and have been practicing these methods for almost two decades in the Walla Walla Valley.⁣
⁣⁣
⁣A central foundation to Horsepower’s philosophy, following Rudolf Steiner’s biodynamic practices, they track the astrological calendar and farm without the use of herbicides, insecticides, fungicides or synthetic fertilizers. Balancing Mother Nature and tending to the earth, Horsepower wines are a throwback to simpler times in our not-so-distant past where we had to embrace the earth, respect its soil and cultivate crops without modern agrochemicals that could degrade the viability of the soil and/or soil microbiota.⁣
⁣⁣
⁣Horsepower Vineyards' commitment to biodynamic farming is paramount, and the team believes it is the best way to create a true balance in the vineyard and make world-class wines that clearly display terroir. ⁣
⁣⁣
⁣⁣More info via our bio link.⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣📸:: @horsepowervineyards

node.text:
RECENTLY PUBLISHED: Australia: Penfolds 2021 Releases. ⁣
⁣⁣
⁣On the red wine side of the ledger, most of the new releases are from the 2019 vintage. While it may not quite equal the heights of 2018, Gago said, "It was a good solid vintage for us. There was a bit of heat, but not like ’20 or ’08. Standouts include the Bin 150 Marananga Shiraz, the Bin 798 RWT Shiraz and the Bin 707 Cabernet Sauvignon. Budget-minded shoppers may want to try the Bin 28 Kalimna Shiraz, which, like the Bin 311 Chardonnay, represents a solid value at $40.⁣
⁣⁣
⁣Read @joeczinsta's full report and 15+ tasting notes via link in bio. ⁣
⁣⁣
⁣📸: @penfolds, @readersdigest
